ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a course where you got out what you put in, and you're very likely to learn a lot from your classmates as many students who are interested in energy access have probably traveled and worked abroad. The readings were often very academic, so it was not always easy to follow the economic analyses. However, given enough time to digest, the readings were useful in helping students understand how academics theorize potential opportunities and their analyses' shortcomings.

The course was useful in providing better understanding of approaches to programs combatting energy poverty. However, the readings and assignments were significantly more time intensive than a standard 1-credit course, and more on-par with the requirements of a 3-credit course.

This course was unorganized and poorly structured. Workload was about 3-4 higher than the standard 1-credit workshop at the School of Management. While knowledgable, Dr. Pauchuri too often allowed class discussions to go unchecked, often going off-topic and entertaining questions and theories that were not relevant to the topics or questions at-hand.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Lots of reading material, and you can deepen your understanding of the issues very quickly. Student-led discussions were more interesting than 1 lecturer speaking to the class for 3 hours at a time.
Class discussions.
Readings and class discussion.

The best aspects of this course was having a practitioner with experience in this field as the instructor.It was easier relating to the examples in class as some of them are on going studies and/or projects. In addition to that,the presentations were more student (working as teams) led giving room for more creativity and deeper engagements.

Class discussion, which was almost just like 3 hours of office hours every two weeks with Shonali. You could ask whatever you wanted, especially as your questions related to the theme of the week. I thought all themes were very relevant.
The course provided a good foundation for understanding the complexities associated with efforts to combat energy poverty and increase energy access in the developing world.
Exposure to the resources provided by Dr. Pauchuri in the class Canvas page.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The readings could be more balanced with more case studies, instead of purely academic papers and global reports.
Discussions could be better moderated by the instructor. No laptop policy should have been encouraged.
I would have liked a little more direct instruction from the professor.
I feel it was well balanced between lecturing and discussions.

I don't think we realized how much work a 1-credit class would be until midway through the semester. It would have been helpful to establish this as a 2-credit class and maybe make the class a few people smaller. I felt that not all my classmates took it seriously by the end. Also, rather than a blog, it would have been easier to just have a few people responsible for a given theme to write up a response as an assignment and have everyone else go around the room and critique/provide feedback. That would have forced students to all be more engaged. The blog format was too lax and challenging to monitor.

The course-load requirements were significantly greater than anticipated, and occasionally redundant. Some of the lectures also did not provide additional information not covered in the required readings.
The course's workload she be adjusted to be commensurate with a one-credit course. Dr. Pauchuri should provide lectures instead of relying entirely on discussion and student-facilitated discussions.
Course load was a bit heavy for the type of scoring done with this class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The course only consisted of a discussion section, so this question is irrelevant.
Discussions could have been better moderated.

The discussions were through blogs,which was quite effective as students were expected to respond comment to blog postings on the topic under review.The lectures were then used as points for answering questions raised and clarifying any ambiguity.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm very interested in working in the Energy Access field, and I feel that I understand some of the issues around the root of the problem, but I didn't gain any skills for how to tackle these problems in the future.
As someone interested in energy issues in developing countries, the course helped me to get a better idea of issues.
The course aligns with my academic and professional interests. I was very excited to take the course.

While I have worked on energy access in a developing county,I have had not hard any course on the same.This class provided an introduction to the energy access question while also providing a valuable forum for discussing the potential solutions in terms of business models,financing and technology that can be used to address the energy access challenges at the least cost.This fits into my interest of energy economics and policy by giving insights into successful business cases and the interaction between environment and energy.Beyond the knowledge gained (which is my area of interest),the presentations and discussions equally sharpens ones' communication skills whereas the blogging and writing the research paper nurtures the writing skills which I believe is of great value for any scientist.

I'm interested in energy finance, so energy access issues are directly related to my interests. It's very valuable to understand the real-world delivery challenges that go with energy access despite well-formulated potential studies.

The course helped me understand where my interests in energy policy lay relative to expansion of renewable energy in off-grid, developing communities or for more centralized infrastructure. This is useful as I seek to narrow my focus on policies to promote renewable energy integration with existing energy investment and infrastructure.
In theory, this course fills a topical gap at SOM / FES. In practice, this course was not helpful.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest.
To learn more about energy access issues in developing countries.
See question 17.

Coming from a developing country,energy access still remains a greater challenge and this class looks at the question of energy access in these countries and the technologies in place to electrify the off-grid population. The modules for the course details how to define and measure the impacts and benefits of energy access.Moreover it gives us an opportunity to think through what acceptable potential approaches would employed in ensuring energy access. The course also offered an opportunity to interact with other students who have worked in advancing energy access in other countries which is valuable as one gains from their perspectives based on practical experience
Because I am interested in renewable energy project development.
To better understand the complexities involved with expansion of renewable energy in the infrastructure of developing countries.
I am passionate about energy access in developing countries and there has been no other committed courses or seminars on this topic at Yale.
Always good to understand energy issues on a global scale. It provided insight into opportunities for improvement and new markets.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I did learn to be more critical, and that's fine, but it's not a "practitioner" style course, and I think this course could benefit from a more practical curriculum. Bring in a speaker or two to discuss the work they're doing (@ Google or Facebook) to tackle energy access. Bring someone in from SE4All, or some global institution! The literature will not be sufficient in such an emerging field.
No.
I learned a lot about the topic. I found the readings and discussion to be beneficial to my academic and professional knowledge.

Yes it did.The course culminated in the writing and presentation of a paper based on one of the modules taught in class.This provided an opportunity for critical analysis of some of the questions that arose during the discussion.
Yes. I learned a lot from the readings and discussions with Shonali and the class.

To some extent, yes, I have a better understanding of the challenges facing expansion of energy in developing countries. However, The course could have spent more time exploring solutions to the problem, rather than the great deal of time spent on defining and identifying the problem.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I liked the group presentations. I leaned a lot from them.

Group work provides an opportunity to interact with individuals with different experiences and views which help enrich your work.Equally,the distribution of labor makes it light and easy to handle especially with extra support from the team. The realization that the outcome in terms of the blog post or class presentation is entirely based on the teams effort creates a desire to own the project and give the best.

It was nice to be able to break up the work, but I felt that my project partner's presentation was too much in the weeds and not relevant to most of the class. He would have been better-served summarizing the purpose of modeling, the various components, and how that ties back to our theme.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a big literature review. Don't expect any practical skills from this course. However, there are interesting energy access issues that I learned about, and now I know how to ask some of the right questions.
It is an opportunity to learn and so come in with an open mind.
You get out what you put in, and you should do your best to read all the readings each week.
The course is useful if you are hoping to work on energy access issues, but to expect a 3-4 credit workload, and plan the rest of your schedule accordingly.
Unfortunately, I would advise against this seminar and instead (1) undertake an independent study on the topic or (2) work with SOM or FES leadership to design a more effective course on the topic.
